entry.title: Security, Data Protection and IAM guidelines in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Security is a fundamental component throughout the entire lifecycle of SAP products, including development, planning, and quality assurance. For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP manages infrastructure-level security such as network protection, operating system security, and patch management. Security responsibilities requiring business-specific decisions‚Äîsuch as user and authorization management‚Äîare handled by the customer. In certain cases, SAP provides secure default configurations, which customers can adjust to suit specific business or integration requirements. Overall, SAP covers key security domains at the platform level, while customers are responsible for application-level security and configuration.

We have now added new Security and Data Protection Guidelines within the SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape) Roadmap.

As an introduction to SAP Activate Methodology, The SAP Activate Roadmaps is a comprehensive, phase-based guide designed to support implementation, conversion, and upgrade projects by defining tasks, deliverables, responsibilities, and accelerators across six key phases: Discover, Prepare, Explore, Realize, Deploy, and Run. It provides methodology guidance, clear role and task allocation, and a rich set of accelerators such as templates and checklists to streamline activities like system provisioning, data migration, and cutover planning. Regularly updated to align with SAP‚Äôs quarterly cloud releases, the roadmap also offers specialized paths for system conversions and upgrades, and integrates with SAP Cloud ALM to enable real-time task management, progress tracking, and agile project execution, ensuring efficient and best-practice-driven project delivery.

Here is an overview of the topics and guidelines covered in each of the phases from a Security & Data Protection perspective

Prepare:

  • Review the recommendations that help you evaluate the security of the configuration of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in your landscape. As part of the cloud shared responsibility model(restricted access), you're responsible for determining if any of these recommendations are relevant to your environment and to what extent.
  • Integrate security recommendations into the overall implementation strategy, ensuring that the security plan comprehensively covers the following areas:
    • Implementation Aspects ‚Äì including evaluation of integration security posture, frontend protection planning, and authentication design;
    • Recurring Topics ‚Äì such as certificate management planning, security monitoring setup, user lifecycle management design, and planning for the security and patching of external software.

These topics are critical to establishing a secure, compliant, and well-governed SAP S/4HANA Cloud environment.

Explore:

  • Conduct Data Protection Workshop

Define and confirm the implementation scope and configuration settings related to data protection and privacy, ensuring compliance with both general and industry-specific legal requirements. The workshop focuses on understanding SAP‚Äôs data protection concepts, identifying relevant project areas such as application design, extensibility, integration, testing, data management, and analytics, and determining where data protection measures must be applied. Key outcomes include clarifying responsibilities, reviewing system configurations, defining data retention policies, and ensuring transparency over personal data processing. The result is a comprehensive plan that outlines required actions for data protection experts and stakeholders to ensure secure and compliant system operations.

  • Plan and Design Identity and Access Management

Plan and design the Identity and Access Management (IAM) framework for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ensuring proper authorization and secure access to applications. This involves consolidating business requirements captured during fit-to-standard workshops, defining a clear authorization concept with naming conventions, specifying required workplaces, and mapping SAP applications and business catalogs to these workplaces. All technical IAM details must be collected, documented, and approved by the customer. The authorization concept should ensure data integrity, protection against misuse, and be transparent enough for third-party verification. The finalized IAM framework also supports test planning and execution.

Realize:

  • Initial access to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Tenants

Setup Integration to Corporate IdP if needed by setting up the SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service as a proxy. Configure password policies and multi-factor authentication (MFA) in your IdP (Identity Authentication service or corporate IdP)

  • Configure data protection and privacy features based on the design defined during the Fit-to-Standard workshop. Key steps include defining data controllers, setting retention and residence policies for transactional and master data, managing security audit log retention, and maintaining purposes for information retrieval. Additionally, configure read access logging and consent administration if applicable.
  • Implement Frontend Security settings focusing on web client protection measures
  • Review and adapt existing Business Catalogs and Business Roles resulting from the addition of new scope items or an upgrade
  • Configure Identity and Access Management

This task involves creating, configuring, and testing custom business roles based on approved identity and access management requirements. It includes assigning business catalogs and restriction field values according to the Application-Workplace List, creating test users, and ensuring roles cover all necessary access through completeness and negative testing. Authorization testing is coordinated across business areas, with roles refined and validated based on feedback.

Deploy:

  • Finalize and validate all security configurations and data protection measures before the system goes live

Run:

  • Security Operations

Maintain system security, compliance, and audit readiness through continuous activities defined in the Prepare phase. Key ongoing operations include regular log monitoring (covering business data changes, user and role changes, and security audits), periodic reviews of Identity and Access Management for business and communication users, and proactive certificate management to prevent expirations and manage trust lists. Additionally, configuration monitoring is performed to ensure system integrity, collectively supporting a secure and compliant SAP environment.

Use the tag Security-Data Protection-IAM to access Security, Data Protection and IAM content in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape) Roadmap

You can explore more SAP Activate resources in SAP Community using tag  #sapactivate, we also encourage you to consider following our sister communities SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Cloud ALM. Let us know your thoughts in the comments to this blog post or via questions in the SAP Activate community.

entry.title: How to get 10000 developers to securely deliver their software
entry.content:
Let‚Äôs start with a few numbers: SAP S/4HANA contains more than 300 million lines of code, the software runs more than 90% of the world‚Äôs largest corporations and, most importantly for the scope of this article, it currently keeps about 10.000 developers at SAP busy. Those developers are spread all over the globe, covering pretty much every time zone. In this challenging setup, how do you ensure the secure delivery of software? Short answer: transparency. Long answer: continue reading.

Obviously, the answer is more complex than that. In order to ensure the security of a software that complex with that many developers in a decentralized setup, quite a few measures have to be in place in order to ensure securely written code and applications. These issues are addressed by SAP, as we have implemented a ‚Äûshift-Left‚Äú approach to security early on, including a product standard for security, a secure development and operations lifecycle (we need to secure our cloud environments, too), and, of course various tools and trainings to support developers in developing secure code in the first place.

Nevertheless, with 10.000 people working on the code daily, overseeing the security posture of the written code can be challenging, to say the least. This is why we have come up with the ‚ÄûSecurity Execution Dashboard‚Äú. At this point, we have to make a confession: there‚Äôs not much new stuff in the dashboard ‚Äì but as with a lot of good things, it‚Äôs the combination of existing features and functions that make the dashboard so powerful ‚Äì and is one of the reasons it won the prestigious CSO50 award this year, making it the second year in a row that SAP was able to win this particular award. Let‚Äôs deep dive into what made the security execution dashboard award-winning.

One of the biggest technical hurdles was the sheer diversity of tools involved. SAP‚Äôs security landscape includes a mix of industry-standard scanners like GitHub, Blackduck, and Checkmarx, as well as SAP‚Äôs own tools like FioriDAST. Each of these tools speaks its own language‚Äîdifferent data formats, different APIs, different update cycles. To make sense of this chaos, the team built a unified data extraction framework. Think of it as a translator that sits between the dashboard and each tool, standardizing the way data is pulled, parsed, and processed. Every tool got its own connector or adapter, ensuring that no matter how the data looked coming in, it would be clean and consistent going out.

But pulling the data was only half the battle. The next challenge was making it meaningful. Security data is only useful if it‚Äôs tied to the right team, the right product, and the right release. That meant building a harmonized data model that could map scan results to specific areas of responsibility. This wasn‚Äôt just a matter of matching names‚Äîit required defining mapping rules, building validation mechanisms, and ensuring that the same issue wasn‚Äôt counted twice or missed entirely. The result is a dashboard that doesn‚Äôt just show you what‚Äôs wrong‚Äîit shows you who needs to fix it.

Performance was another sticking point. Querying live data from all these tools in real time would have brought the system to its knees. So the team implemented caching and temporary in-memory storage to keep things fast and responsive. Frequently accessed data is now stored locally, reducing the load on source systems and ensuring that developers aren‚Äôt left waiting for their dashboards to load.

Data quality also proved to be a recurring issue. In the early days, scan results were often misattributed or incomplete, making it hard to trust the insights. To fix this, the team introduced a robust data quality management process. Automated validation checks, regular audits, and feedback loops with tool owners helped tighten the accuracy of the data and improve the reliability of team mappings.

And then there was the human side. Convincing thousands of developers to adopt a new tool‚Äîespecially one that shines a light on security gaps‚Äîis no small feat. The team tackled this with a mix of early engagement, pilot programs, and a strong internal communications push. Over time, the dashboard earned its place as the go-to source for security insights, not by mandate, but by proving its value.

Today, the Security Execution Dashboard is more than just a reporting tool. It‚Äôs a living system that adapts to the needs of SAP‚Äôs engineering teams. It‚Äôs fast, it‚Äôs accurate, and it‚Äôs deeply integrated into the way SAP builds software. And most importantly, it‚Äôs helped shift the conversation around security‚Äîfrom something that happens after the fact, to something that‚Äôs embedded from the very first line of code.

entry.title: High-Availability Setup for SAP Secure Login Service with Microsoft Azure Traffic Manager
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI is SAP‚Äôs solution for secure authentication and single sign-on in SAP GUI scenarios. The service is based on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) and supports the platform capabilities for high availability (HA).

In most cases this will be sufficient for customers, in particular as SAP Secure Login Service is only required during an end-user‚Äôs initial authentication of the day. When this is successful, an X.509 certificate is deployed on the end-user desktop, which gives her single sign-on, usually for the rest of the working day.

Still, some customers would like to go beyond the standard HA capabilities and instead implement a dedicated, multi-region failover setup.

In this blog, I will describe the steps that are necessary to configure this setup. It is based on SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI, SAP Custom Domain service and Microsoft Azure Traffic Manager. Many thanks to Microsoft‚Äôs @MartinRaepple for helping me get started with Traffic Manager. This blog is yet another outcome of our great collaboration over the years üôÇ

 

Setting up SAP Secure Login Service for multi-region failover

 

  1. Subscribe to SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI from two SAP BTP subaccounts in different regions, in the same global account. Let us assume that the two instances of SAP Secure Login Service have the URLs sls-customer.region1.cloud.sap and sls-customer.region2.cloud.sap.
  2. In each region, configure the same custom domain and map it to the local SAP Secure Login Service standard route. Let us assume that the custom domain has the URL sls.customer.com. For the custom domain to work, you also need to add the OpenID Connect redirect URIs in SAP Cloud Identity Services ‚Äì Identity Authentication.
  3. Introduce a traffic management solution. In this example, we use Microsoft Azure Traffic Manager. Let us assume that the Traffic Manager profile has the URL sls.trafficmanager.net. Add the URLs of the two SAP Secure Login Service instances as endpoints to the Traffic Manager profile.
  4. Configure the routing method, based on which Traffic Manager will switch end points. For testing, you might use the priority of the end points, which means that the switch takes place if you change the priority in the Traffic Manager configuration. In a productive scenario, you would choose technical indicators of availability, such as performance.
  5. Traffic Manager will automatically configure the DNS record of sls.trafficmanager.net to point to the optimal endpoint, based on the routing method. Let us assume that in the beginning this is region 1.
  6. Configure the DNS record of your custom domain sls.customer.com so that it points to the Traffic Manager URL sls.trafficmanager.net.
  7. Enter the custom domain sls.customer.com as the SAP Secure Login Service host name in Secure Login Client on the end-user desktop.
     

 

Handling of the failover case

 

  1. Let us assume that due to some technical reason, SAP Secure Login Service in region 1 becomes unresponsive.
  2. Traffic Manager checks all endpoints at regular intervals (e.g., every 10 seconds) and detects the issue.
  3. Traffic Manager updates the DNS record for sls.trafficmanager.net to point to sls-customer.region2.cloud.sap.
  4. The next time Secure Login Client connects to SAP Secure Login Service, the DNS name sls.customer.com is automatically resolved to point to the service instance in region 2.

 

Further considerations

This blog covers the high-availability setup of SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI. As SAP Secure Login Service relies on an identity provider for end-user authentication, this also needs to be available at runtime. SAP‚Äôs identity provider, SAP Cloud Identity Services ‚Äì Identity Authentication, also offers a multi-region setup. If you use a 3rd party identity provider, check the documentation of that product to learn more about options for high availability.

SAP Secure Login Service issues end-user certificates that enable authentication for SAP NetWeaver ABAP-based systems such as SAP ERP and SAP S/4HANA. During authentication, the X.509 certificate is mapped to a user account in the ABAP system, if the SNC name of that user account matches the subject name of the certificate. In the default implementation of SAP Secure Login Service, information about the region becomes part of the subject name. As a result, switching to a different region breaks the mapping.

There are two options to ensure that the SNC mapping remains intact:

  • Use parameters of the SAP Cryptographic Library to strip the region names from the certificate subject before the mapping takes place. That way, certificates from different regions will match the same SNC name. See note 2338952 for details.
  • Change the SAP Secure Login Service configuration to use a customer-managed certificate authority. This gives you the option to customize the subject name of the certificate so that it does not include the BTP region.

 

Conclusion

Setting up SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI for multi-region failover is easy. All you need is SAP Custom Domain service and a traffic management solution such as Microsoft Azure Traffic Manager. Thanks to the flexibility of the configuration, end-users continue to benefit from single sign-on even if SAP Secure Login Service instances are switched in the background.

 

More information

For more information about our SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI solution and to stay up to date on the latest developments, visit our topic page in SAP Community. Also, take a look at @MartinRaepple's blog SAP GUI MFA with Microsoft Entra: Integration with SAP Secure Login Service.

entry.title: Deploy built-in SAP LogServ detection rules in Microsoft Sentinel and extend to your needs - Part 3
entry.content:
Find your way to our central blog series entry here.

Dear community,

Following the product release blog by SAP regarding the integration of SAP LogServ and Microsoft Sentinel, I am going to share some details on the built-in detection rules and how you can build upon them.

The most discussed log in my customer conversations so far was SAP HANA database. So, let‚Äôs start with that.

 

Discover the available built-in detections from the Content Hub

Find the relevant section both from the Azure or the unified Defender portal under Rule templates in the Analytics section. They are available from version 3.0.2 of the SAP LogServ solution.

 

Typical database threat scenarios involve tampering with audit log settings, admin authorizations or privileged role assignments.

We have taken the existing battle-proven Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP rules for HANA DB and translated them to be compatible with the LogServ schema. The raw log source is Syslog in both cases. So, the only remaining step was ‚Äúunboxing‚Äù of the JSON wrapper.

To understand the individual columns of the LogServ output, see SAP‚Äôs HANA Audit Trail Layout for Trail Target documentation. For ease of use we have numbered the columns and applied the same names SAP mentions on their docs.

 

Activate the new rules

Navigate to the Analytics pane and select the rule you want, click ‚ÄúCreate Rule‚Äù from the button with the three dots and follow the configuration wizard. See the severity classification and pre-defined MITRE attack framework mapping. These mappings help streamline your SOC analysts‚Äô triage efforts.

 

 

Verify the rule execution schedule and consider automated responses where feasible. Creating ServiceNow tickets for instance is a popular action. See my dedicated blog series on SOAR for SAP for inspiration.

From the ‚ÄúReview + Create‚Äù section click save. Your rule is now live!

 

Build upon or extend the provided analytic rules

Since the Kusto Query is fully transparent to you (see above screenshot) it is easy to derive your own tailored scenarios from it.

For instance, take analytic rule ‚ÄúDeactivation of Audit Trail‚Äù and extend the client IP address attribute (client_ip_address__col_7) to project in plain English if that is an internal or external IP.

| extend GeoLocation= iff(ipv4_is_private(client_ip_address__col_7),
dynamic({"IsPrivate": true}),
geo_info_from_ip_address(client_ip_address__col_7))

I have a feeling this might be of interest during your incident triage process üòâ

 

Final Words

That‚Äôs a wrapüåØ. You saw today how to discover the built-in analytic rules of the SAP LogServ solution in Microsoft Sentinel and how easy it is to extend them for your own individual needs. The rule catalog gets extended continuously based on customer demand.

Your existing investments in SAP infrastructure detections in Sentinel can easily be made compatible with the LogServ schema, because SAP simply forwards the logs unaltered as raw messages. The only required step is the unboxing of their JSON root message.

#Kudos to @Hemanth_Kusampudi and team for the partnership.

Get started with your deployment from here today.

Which detections or analytic rules for RISE do you need most? Let me know in the comments or reach out directly.

Cheers Martin

entry.title: First smoke test after SAP LogServ solution deployment in Microsoft Sentinel - Part 0
entry.content:
Find your way to our central blog series entry here.

Dear community,

Due to the asynchronous integration between SAP LogServ and Microsoft Sentinel, it's advisable to perform a smoke test yourself before sharing your config data with SAP. This helps confirm if your receiving connector setup works and ensures the correct configuration will be shared with SAP the first time round.

 

Run a smoke test for ease of mind

Once the SAP LogServ push-connector is deployed on Microsoft Sentinel, you can start posting data towards its data collection endpoint. Use the provided REST client collection, or scripts to replicate the exact requests details that LogServ is performing too.

Maintain the variables as per your environment, see the LogServ sample payload and start posting. A working request shows http code 204 with no content on the response. See a sample output from the provided powershell script for reference. I prefer REST clients but people are different üòé

 

Find the parameters from the SAP LogServ Sentinel connector wizard on initial connect (see screenshot below). You can also get them directly from the individual resources. The data collection endpoint and data collection rule are created in the same resource group as your Log Analytics workspace underpinning Sentinel. They are prefixed with ‚ÄúSAPLogServ‚Äù. The app registration on Entra ID can be found from the Entra Application ID field.

 

Use the 2 KQL queries below to inspect your first data entry on the SAPLogServ_CL table in Sentinel.

SAPLogServ_CL
| take 10
SAPLogServ_CL
| summarize count() by clz_dir, clz_subdir
| order by clz_dir asc, clz_subdir asc

 

Wait a minute or two on first try. The population of new tables takes a short time initially.

Alternatively, deploy the SAP LogServ insights workbook on Sentinel for visual oversight. 

 

Once saved to your workspace, start looking for the smoke test result. It covers all your observabilty needs going forward.

 

Hurray you have a functioning data collection endpoint for the SAP LogServ dataüéâ

Now, continue your onboarding journey by sharing the config data with SAP over your chosen channel. Find the details on SAP's blog here.

What if you don‚Äôt see the data entry on the LogServ table?

  1. Verify the connection details: Did you really hit the right endpoint? Are you looking in the right tenant and log analytics workspace?
  2. Verify selection criteria: Is your Time range filter accurate? The smoke tests create entries for NOW or 30mins earlier in UTC.
  3. Did enough time pass on the initial table population? Consider a retry of the KQL query.
  4. Verify the Data collection rule has not been changed to filter all results or similar. See this blog part and KQL snippet for more details.

 

Deployment fully messed up?

The simplest way to a fresh start is a delete and redeployment of the Log Analytics workspace. In case that is not an option you need to delete the LogServ connector resources to reset the LogServ solution in Sentinel. The data collection endpoint, data collection rule and entra id app registration can be deleted from the Azure portal. But the data connector itself needs to be deleted via API.

For your convenience, use this REST API request collection to drop the resources. Once performed the LogServ connector UI will activate the deploy button again. In case you went fully bazooka and also deleted the SAPLogServ_CL table from your Log Analytics worksapce that needs to be reverted too. If the table had data you need to run a restore operation from Azure CLI.

 

Final Words

That‚Äôs a wrapüåØ. You saw today how to streamline your onboarding experience of SAP LogServ in Microsoft Sentinel. Simple smoke tests ensure a speedy onboarding and confidence in the shared setup configuration.

#Kudos to @Hemanth_Kusampudi and team for the partnership.

Get started with your deployment from here today.

Cheers Martin

entry.title: Q2 2025: Quarterly Release Highlights: SAP BTP Security and Identity & Access Management
entry.content:
In the second quarter of 2025, we released several new features and enhancements. Did you know that you can find all new feature announcements for SAP Cloud Identity Services in the SAP Cloud Identity Services Release Notes on the SAP Help Portal?

Let‚Äôs take a look at some of our recent highlights!

Identity Provisioning Service: Job log improvements

The Job Execution Outcome is now displayed on the Job Execution Details screen and included in the job notifications. It appears when delta-read jobs and jobs that fail to read entities from the source system affect the deletion of entities in the target system.
For more information, see Monitor Provisioning Job Logs.

You can now download and view the details of all deleted entities by a provisioning job. To enable this, set the property ips.trace.deleted.entity to true.
For more information, see Manage Provisioning Job Logs and List of Properties.

Identity Directory Service and Identity Provisioning Service: Support for extension schemas towards many SAP business applications

We now support a number of extension schemas, including

  • SAP extension schema for groups
  • Extension enterprise schema for users
  • SAP ODM User Schema Support

You can find details in the SAP Cloud Identity Release Notes.

Extension of the Identity Directory‚Äôs SCIM API

The Identity Directory API of SAP Cloud Identity Services now returns the termsOfUse and privacyPolicy parameters. For more information, check Identity Directory API.

In addition, we now support application-specific group assignments. You can find details in the SAP Help Portal chapters on Identity Authentication and the Local Identity Directory.

Management of Corporate Identity Providers via API

Tenant administrators can manage corporate identity providers in Identity Authentication via API. It offers endpoints for CRUD operations (GET, POST, PATCH, DELETE) over the corporate identity providers. See SAP Cloud Identity Services Corporate Identity Providers Directory.

Configuration of Password Expiration Reminder

You can configure the system to show a password expiration reminder on the user‚Äôs sign-in page. For more information, check Enable Password Expiration Reminder.

Enabling SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI with support for Microsoft Windows mandatory profiles

We added support for single sign-on on shopfloor Windows-based computers that are configured to use a mandatory profile. This protects shopfloor computers with a restrictive mandatory profile while still offering single sign-on support for desktop clients of SAP GUI. You can find more information in the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Cloud Foundry Login Based on JSON Web Tokens (JWTs)

When building CI/CD pipelines, developers are responsible for managing the credentials used by these pipelines for authentication to external systems. This traditionally requires developers to take care of the lifecycle of the credentials, including secure storage and regular rotation of the credentials, which comes with repeated efforts and might be error-prone.

In his latest blog post, Authenticating GitHub Actions Workflows Deploying to the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry Environment with JWTs, Sebastian Ries explains how to authenticate to the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment from a GitHub Actions workflow using GitHub-issued short-lived JSON Web Tokens (JWTs), eliminating the need for manual secret management and enabling secure, efficient CI/CD workflows. 

Want to stay up to date on our services? Join our SAP BTP Security, Single Sign-On for SAP GUI and SAP Cloud Identity Services communities!

entry.title: Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part I - Getting Started
entry.content:
The APIs for process automation are quite important to building integration scenarios with processes. But many people do not know how to get started, and even experienced users do not know how to work with environments or how to handle authentication or when an API key is needed.

So here is a guide to the APIs.

NOTE: I assume that you already know how to work with process automation, and you know the ins and outs of creating and triggering process projects using the SAP Build UI.

 

What can you do with APIs

If you just use forms to trigger a process, and then the process runs with actions and approval forms, you may not need to use the APIs. But most sophisticated processes will require you to make use of the APIs. So here is a list of some of things you can do with the APIs:

  • Trigger a process (sending in input values)
  • Get the status of a process instance
  • Get the context and execution log of a process instance
  • Change the status of a process instance (such as suspend or cancel)
  • Get a list of existing processes
  • Get a list of open user tasks
  • Approve or reject an approval form
  • Execute any form, and select which button of the form to simulate pressing
  • Call a decision (business rule) to get the appropriate output
  • Get a list of automation jobs that were run
  • ... and much more

 

Where to get information on APIs

The best place to go to get basic reference information about the APIs is, of course, the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Search for Process Automation, and then under APIs you will see the package of APIs.

Click the SAP Build Process Automation package, and you will see 1 OData API and 6 REST API. The key APIs are the REST APIs. 

Here's a link to get to the SAP Build Process Automation package directly.

 

Authentication and Permissions

The most complex part of working with the APIs is the authentication, and understanding the types of authentication and what each enables you to do.

2 Main Authentication Methods

There are 2 main ways to perform OAuth2 authentication:

  • Client Credentials, where you are signing in as the service, which has essentially admin rights (but not complete access to all information)
  • User Token, where you are signing in as a user (you) with whatever rights you have been given, both in terms of process automation roles and permissions in a specific SAP Build environment (more on environments later)

Why is this important?

Because you often want to know who the user is who is calling the API. For example, when triggering a process, the user who makes the API call is the one listed in the Monitoring tab. If that's not important, you can use client credentials with a service key.

Or, if you are retrieving workflow instances from an environment, only a member from that environment with the correct permissions can access the workflow instances. Using client credentials with the client id/secret will not work.

Client Credentials

To connect, with Client Credentials, you send a Client ID and Client Secret, derived from the service key.

In the cockpit, where you created an instance of the SAP Build Process Automation service, you need to create a service key. 

You only need supply a name for the key.

Once you create the key, you can view the key's detail by clicking View.

This displays something like this:

You only need the following fields to log in:

  • api: The host of the APIs
  • clientid: Username
  • clientsecret: Password
  • url: Authentication URL to get the authorization token (the URL is this URL with /oauth/token appended)

So if you were setting up a destination, this is how it would work:

User Token

But many times, perhaps most times, you do not want to use a service user but you want to know who is making the call. This is important, for example, if the call is to approve the task, so only the user to whom the task is assigned should be updating the task. Or, as we mentioned above, only a real member of an environment can retrieve workflow instances from a shared environment.

With a destination, the only change you need to make is to change the Authentication field to OAuth2JWTBearer, and this will make sure to retrieve and send a token for the current user. All other destination fields are the same.

Environments

With the relatively new shared environments (i.e., all environments except Public), you sometimes need to indicate in the API call to which environment you are making the call to. For example, a process may be deployed to multiple environments, so when you call to trigger it, you need to specify in which environment to trigger it.

To do this, you add this query parameter:

?environmentId=MyEnvironment

Similarly, if you want to retrieve all the process instances from a particular environment, your API URL might look like this:

https://spa-api-gateway-bpi-us-prod.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=danielshared

 

Try Out on Accelerator Hub

Let's try to access our SAP Build Process Automation process instances from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Go to the GET workflow-instances API. On the left menu, click Workflow Instances, and then select the first API call.

Click Add New Environment on the right, and fill in the details using the values from your service key.

Call the environment My Trial BTP, select the authentication domain for your tenant (for my trial account it was http://authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/) and then when entering the consumer subdomain, only enter the subdomain for your subaccount. 

At the bottom indicate you want to save the environment for the future, and click Configure. It might take a minute for the configuration to save.

Then, on the right, select the environment, and click Run. You should get your workflow instances.

entry.title: Securing Agentic AI Through Threat Modeling at SAP
entry.content:
By Helen Oakley, Senior Director of Software and AI Security, SAP Global Security & Cloud Compliance 

This year, at SAP Sapphire, SAP unveiled its expanded vision for Business AI, introducing a growing network of Joule Agents that work across systems and lines of business. This marks a clear step into the era of Agentic AI ‚Äì systems that can understand context, take initiative, and drive outcomes autonomously. ‚ÄúSAP combines the world‚Äôs most powerful suite of business applications with uniquely rich data and the latest AI innovations to create a flywheel of customer value,‚Äù said CEO Christian Klein. While this evolution opens exciting possibilities for automation and productivity, it also introduces a new layer of complexity in how we approach security. Agentic systems challenge traditional safeguards, making it essential to identify and mitigate risks early through tailored threat modeling. 

At its core, threat modeling is about asking the right questions early in the development process, while the system is still being designed and built. Rather than simply looking for bugs or code flaws, it forces us to think through how a system might behave in the real world. What could go wrong if an agent‚Äôs goals are manipulated? Could someone poison its memory over time? What if an agent uses a tool in an unintended or unsafe way? How could agent-generated content be used to mislead or overload human decision-makers? What happens when agents collaborate or collide in ways that expose the system to cascading failures or manipulation? 

These are not hypothetical questions. They reflect the real and emerging risks of agentic systems. The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide is a valuable resource that brings structure to this thinking. It highlights specific threats such as memory poisoning, cascading hallucinations, privilege compromise, and agent communication poisoning. For teams building these systems, it helps provide a common vocabulary and practical examples to guide threat modeling work. 

To give an example of how threat modeling helps in practice, let‚Äôs take the case of goal manipulation ‚Äì one of the emerging risks identified in the OWASP guide. In agentic systems, attackers don‚Äôt necessarily need to exploit traditional software flaws. Instead, they can attempt to influence an agent‚Äôs behavior over time by subtly manipulating its objectives. This might happen through indirect prompt injection, compromised data sources, or crafted tool responses. Imagine an agent responsible for prioritizing financial transactions; if adversarial inputs gradually shift its decision logic, it could start approving risky payments outside of the intended policy. In threat modeling exercises, we explore how such scenarios could play out by analyzing how the agent forms and updates its goals, how memory and feedback loops could reinforce undesired behaviors, and how downstream actions might be impacted. This helps define targeted mitigations, such as isolating goal-setting logic from external inputs, monitoring shifts in agent behavior, and adding human validation for sensitive decisions. 

The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide provides a helpful reference architecture that illustrates where these types of risks can emerge. The diagram below maps threats to key components in a typical agentic system, making it easier to visualize how threat modeling applies in practice. 

Image Source: OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations guide, ‚ÄúThreat Model Summary‚Äù 

At SAP, threat modeling has long been part of our Secure Software Development and Operations Lifecycle (Secure SDOL), which is certified under ISO 27001. This framework ensures security is built into every phase of the product lifecycle, from design to operations. With Agentic AI, we are expanding our threat modeling approach to address risks that don‚Äôt typically appear in traditional application security. This includes analyzing agent memory behavior, reasoning patterns, system autonomy, human interaction points, and the dynamics of multi-agent ecosystems. The focus shifts from identifying static vulnerabilities to understanding how autonomy and learning can lead to unintended behaviors. From there, we define appropriate controls and mitigations to reduce those risks. 

The field of Agentic AI security continues to take shape. Standards like ISO 42001 and regulations such as the EU AI Act are in development, and industry best practices are actively maturing. That‚Äôs why collaboration is essential. SAP is contributing to the conversations held with industry groups focused on these challenges, including OWASP GenAI initiatives. We‚Äôre not just adopting ideas, we‚Äôre helping shape them, working with peers and regulators to advance the state of AI security. Our teams bring deep expertise in both enterprise security and AI systems, offering a perspective that‚Äôs helping guide how the broader ecosystem approaches agentic risks. 

Transparency remains central to how SAP approaches product security. As we continue evolving our work with AI, we‚Äôre committed to sharing what we learn through resources like the SAP Trust Center. Security is not a one-time effort. It is a continuous process, especially with systems as dynamic as Agentic AI. 

Threat modeling helps us stay ahead of these evolving risks and supports the design of systems that are both capable and safe. As Agentic AI becomes more embedded in enterprise workflows, this kind of proactive thinking becomes essential. 

SAP is proud to contribute to shaping the future of secure AI. By collaborating across the industry and applying deep expertise from our teams, we‚Äôre helping advance practical, forward-looking approaches to securing the next generation of intelligent systems.

entry.title: Navigating the BP transaction Authorizations in S/4HANA : SAP Security Experts Guide
entry.content:
General Overview

The Business Partner (BP) transaction is the central tool for managing customer and vendor master data in SAP S/4HANA. For many customers, this represents a transition from older transactions like XK01, FK01, and FD01. This change is part of the core data model redesign in S/4HANA, aimed at consolidating customer and vendor information into a single, unified repository. By doing so, it eliminates data redundancy and streamlines business processes. This approach is often also referred to as Customer-Vendor Integration (CVI).

This shift has many SAP Security consultants scratching their heads. The consolidated transaction called BP in S/4HANA combines functionality from over 60 legacy transactions into one powerful master transaction. While efficient, This simplification introduces a lot of complexity ‚Äî particularly for security.

When you check the SU24 data for the BP transaction, you'll find it can include anywhere from 20 to 80 authorization objects. While this extensive list provides fine-grained control over access‚Äîwhich is great from a security standpoint‚Äîit can also be overwhelming. Assigning the BP transaction to a PFCG role often means suddenly facing the task of maintaining values for 30 or more authorization objects, which few enjoy dealing with.

Another challenge with the BP transaction is that, despite having a large number of authorization objects available to control access, many of these checks are inactive by default. As a result, the transaction appears to offer granular control, but in reality, it lacks many essential authorization checks‚Äîmaking it difficult to enforce precise access restrictions.

If your organization has a central team managing master data, you may not encounter some of the challenges mentioned earlier. However, in scenarios involving geographically distributed teams and decentralized master data management, maintaining effective authorizations for the BP transaction can become a significant issue.

Now that we‚Äôve identified the challenges, let‚Äôs explore how to tackle them. In this blog, I‚Äôll clarify and break down the key authorization objects you can use to manage BP authorizations more effectively.

What all transactions BP replaced

Lets start with the basics, the following transaction codes are no longer available as standalone transactions in the S/4HANA system. You can verify the updated list by checking the PRGN_CORR2 table using transaction SE16 in your system.

  • FD01, FD02, FD03, FD05, FD06, FD08
  • FK01, FK02, FK03, FK05, FK06, FK08
  • MAP1, MAP2, MAP3
  • MK01, MK02, MK03, MK05, MK06, MK12, MK18, MK19
  • V-03, V-04, V-05, V-06, V-07, V-08, V-09, V-11, V+21, V+22, V+23
  • VAP1, VAP2, VAP3
  • VD01, VD02, VD03, VD05, VD06
  • XD01, XD02, XD03, XD05, XD06, XD07
  • XK01, XK02, XK03, XK05, XK06, XK07

It‚Äôs important to note that while you may still assign these transactions to users, executing them in S/4HANA typically redirects the user to the BP transaction, often accompanied by an informational message at the bottom of the screen "Redirecting to transaction BP"

‚ÄÉ

Managing the Authorizations for Business Partner transaction

Just like restricting any other transaction in SAP, restricting BP transactions comes down to the correct restrictions across various authorization objects. We will go through these one by one. Lets start then,

When you Execute the BP transaction you are shown this initial screen(see figure) where you can search for a Business Partner(Customer, Vendor etc) using various criterias.

  • ‚úÖ As expected an initial S_TCODE - checks for start transaction code access happens here. Nothing complicated so far,

Once you select a Business Partner the details of the business partner id displayed(see figure), and a lot of authorization checks happens at this level, this is where things gets complicated as well. Lets look at these one by one :

  • ‚úÖ B_BUPA_RLT Business Partner: BP Roles

This Authorization object controls what BP role a uses has, these BP Role (don't confuse these with PFCG roles) defines what functions a user can perform (ACTVT) and also controls the assignment blocks visible in the BP screen(RLTYP). For example:- If the user selects "Business Partner(Gen.)" Role from the dropdown, it allows editing of basic(general) data of the BP. But if the users switches to a different role "Customer" then some additional tabs will open up where data relevant to cutomers can be maintained.

Although, SAP Delivers some standard BP roles these can still be configured and created in SPRO img configuration by your functional team if need arises.

SPRO ‚Üí Cross-Application Components ‚Üí SAP Business Partner ‚Üí Business Partner ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚Üí Business Partner Roles ‚ÜíDefine BP Roles

Read more about this here - https://me.sap.com/notes/3416144

Next is,

  • ‚úÖ B_BUPA_GRP Business Partner: Authorization Groups

With this authorization object, you define which business partners can be edited on the basis of the authorization groups. Now this authorization is optional and You therefore do not have to assign this authorization if there is no master data requiring special protection.

This groups restrictions require 3 things to work properly -

  1. SPRO configuration which can be done here : SPRO ‚Üí Cross-Application Components ‚Üí SAP Business Partner ‚Üí Business Partner ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚ÜíAuthorization Management -> Maintain Authorization Groups
  2. The group needs to be maintained in master data , this can be done via opening the Business partner in general role, Navigate to the Control tab of the BP screen, then maintaining the Authorization Group here. (see screenshot below)
  3. Include authorization object in the role assinged to the user with restrictions. Read more about this here - https://me.sap.com/notes/3416153

Next,

Based on whether you have opened Customer or Vendor different set of authorization will be checked.

  • For Customer - F_KNA1* authorization objects will be checked.
  • For Vendors - F_LFA1* authorization objects will be checked.

‚úÖ F_KNA1_GEN/ F_LFA1_GEN - This authorization object controls which activities are permitted for the general data. The general data consists of the fields that are independent of the company code and the sales organization. This only has single authorization field for ACTVT

 
‚úÖ F_KNA1_GRP/ F_LFA1_GRP - You use this authorization object to specify which activities are permitted for the individual account groups. The object consists of the "Activity" and "Account Group" fields. Note that this groups is different from the group in - B_BUPA_GRP.
 

‚ÄÉ‚úÖ F_KNA1_APP/ F_LFA1_APP - You use this authorization object to determine which activities are allowed for customer/Vendor master records. The object is defined with the fields "Activity" and "Application authorization".

For all of these F_* authorization objects, You will get suggestion and pressing "F1" on the authorization objects will give you some help. These authorizations objects are well known adn documented.

Other Important Authorization objects

Apart from the major objects mentioned above, some of the other important objects are mentioned below. Most of these can be configured at location - SPRO ‚Üí Cross-Application Components ‚Üí SAP Business Partner ‚Üí Business Partner ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚Üí Authorization Management

 

  • ‚úÖ B_BUPA_ATT - This authorization object is optional and is typically used to restrict users to entering only specific values for certain fields. For Example: Suppose a user should only be allowed to create Business Partners with the country set to India. In this case, you can use this authorization object to ensure the user can only enter "IN" in the country field. Any attempt to use a different country code would be blocked based on this restriction. You can read more about this configuration here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3416118/E
  • ‚úÖ B_BUPA_FDG = Authorization object B_BUPA_FDG on BP is used exclusively for field level customization. The user can enforce authorization on the fields in the BP screen. The user for example can set a particular field on the screen as display only even in the change mode for the business partner. You can read more about this configuration here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3416138/E
  • ‚úÖ B_CCARD = You can use this object to regulate authorization for display and/or maintenance of payment card master data.
  • ‚úÖ B_CCSEC = Use this authorization object to define who can display unmasked credit card numbers and who can evaluate or delete the access logs.
 
Some other authorization objects which control the Sales area and Company code level details of Business Partners are - V_KNA1_VKO, M_LFM1_EKO, F_KNA1_BUK, F_LFA1_BUK etc.

 

Miscelleneous

If you are still struggling with restricting access properly for BP transaction, You may find some of the below helpful :

‚ú≥Ô∏èCreate role with just 1 transaction - BP in it. Infact you can have multiple versions of such roles with various degree of access to the single BP transaction. These roles then can be incorporated into Composite roles for better administration. Your roles will look something like this:

  • ZBP_VENDOR - BP role with access to only Vendor(Supplier) Master Data
  • ZBP_CUSTOMER - BP role with access to only Customer Master Data
  • ZBP_MASTERDATA_ALL - BP role with Full access to both Customers & Vendors
  • ZBP_DISPLAY_ALL - BP role with Display all access

You can follow this helpful guide for role creation - Business Partner Authorization Tips and Tricks

‚ú≥Ô∏èIn SU24, you can set the check indicator for unused authorization objects linked to the BP transaction to "No". For rarely used authorization objects, setting them to "Yes, Inactive Default" helps keep things tidy. This simple step significantly reduces clutter and simplifies role maintenance.

‚ú≥Ô∏èWhen troubleshooting, start by checking the user buffer using transaction SU56. If the user has multiple single roles assigned, they might be receiving access to the relevant authorization object from one of these roles‚Äîeffectively bypassing the intended restrictions on the BP transaction.

‚ú≥Ô∏èEnsure that the authorization object is included in the user's profile‚Äîthis is especially important for optional objects like B_BUPA_FDG, which can be used to restrict access to specific fields within the BP transaction. If this object is not included in the user's role, or if it exists in an inactive state. The system will ignore the restrictions, and the user will have unrestricted access to the field. The system only enforces restrictions if the object is present and active in the user master record.

‚ú≥Ô∏èAlthough rare, there are cases where the SAP system may not behave as expected or fail to respect certain authorization checks‚Äîpotentially due to a system issue on SAP‚Äôs end. We encountered such a scenario where the system was incorrectly checking for activity "05" (Block) on F_LFA1_GRP objects even when simply displaying a Business Partner. SAP acknowledged the issue and provided a correction through an OSS Notes. https://me.sap.com/notes/3097438/E , https://me.sap.com/notes/3093933/E

‚ú≥Ô∏èFor handling complex scenarios or implementing custom logic, you can collaborate with your functional and development teams to explore available BADIs or customer exits that may be leveraged. Refer to the resources below to explore such solutions in more detail:

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NKlshC0uyyE
  • https://me.sap.com/notes/0002606686
  • https://me.sap.com/notes/2309153

entry.title: Integrating SAP CIS with SAP SuccessFactors: A Guide to Standard and Hybrid Integration
entry.content:
Overview

SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) is a robust suite of tools designed to manage identity and access across the SAP ecosystem. This blog explores how CIS integrates with SAP SuccessFactors, focusing on hybrid integration patterns that enable seamless user authentication and identity provisioning in complex enterprise landscapes.

There are three primary flavors to integrating

  1. Standard Integration (Recommended)
  2. Proxy Integration using CIS(external IDP as authentication provider)
  3. Hybrid Integration using CIS (external IDP or both external IDP and CIS as authentication provider) without SF being the source of user records to CIS

 SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Cloud Identity Services:

Option 1: Integration Between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP CIS (Standard)

This is the most recommended method, fully aligned with SAP‚Äôs best practices for managing user identities. It involves the following steps:

  1. Integrate SAP SuccessFactors with Identity Authentication: Run the upgrade job in the SAP SuccessFactors Upgrade Center to enable features and establish trust between SF and CIS.
  2. Confirm that user sync is set up in Identity Provisioning in SAP Cloud Identity Services: Set up sync jobs with Identity Provisioning. Ensure that the user that is configured in the Identity Provisioning
  3. Review the default configurations: Review the default configuration of the Identity Authentication service to determine if it meets your requirements or if additional configuration is required.
  4. Additional configuration optional features:Configuration options in Identity Authentication include:  Password policy settings, Single sign-on (SSO) etc
  5. Activate Identity Authentication (IAS): Turn on the Identity Authentication service

This ensures standardized, low-effort configuration and a consistent integration experience. More Details - SAP Help

Option 2: Using SAP CIS as a Proxy (Standard)

Many enterprises already use external identity providers (e.g., Azure AD, Okta) and want to continue doing so while adopting SAP applications.

By integrating the external IdP with CIS, organizations can:

  • Maintain centralized identity governance.
  • Enable secure authentication across SAP SuccessFactors, SAC, and Joule.

In this approach CIS acts as a proxy and user authentication is taken care by the external Identity provider like Entra, OKTA, etc. CIS may/may not have user records in its internal store (based on your requirements). Federation can be used if user records exist. Synching user records in CIS unlock features like SAC and future innovations such as SAP Joule, as they're a key prerequisite for access. Ideal for customers wanting minimal disruption to existing identity infrastructure while gaining access to SAP‚Äôs innovation roadmap.

Option 3: Hybrid Integration ‚Äî Using SAP CIS as a Proxy Without Standard SF User Sync.

Further details in this blog primarily focuses on this hybrid model.

Key Characteristics:

  • SAP SuccessFactors is not the user provisioning source.
  • CIS can act as a proxy or both proxy and IDP
  • User profile data is synced to CIS from a different /external source to enable:
    • Access to services like SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Joule
    • Federated authentication via external IdPs

This method provides the flexibility to maintain external Identity manager to keep managing users in an enterprise while using SAP CIS to enabling access to SAP applications and to access new features and innovations.

‚öôÔ∏èUnderstanding Standard Integration Behavior

SAP‚Äôs standard SF-to-CIS integration includes two background jobs(in case if SAC exist):

Job 1: User Sync from SuccessFactors to IAS

  • Reads user data from SF.
  • Creates users in CIS.
  • Generates a Global User ID, and store it in personKeyNav/GlobalUserId in SF.
  • Populates CustomAttribute1 if the user has SAC access permissions.

Job 2: Sync to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  • Reads user data from SF and syncs only users with access to embedded analytics to SAC
  • Prevents SAC user creation for ineligible accounts.

‚öôÔ∏èAdapting the Integration for an External Data Source

If you're not syncing users from SAP SF (i.e., using an external Data source like Identity manager), the standard jobs need to be customized to use IAS as the source and SAC as the target. It is very important to make sure that only users who have permission to embedded analytics should be synched to SAC. This step can be done either inside the cync job or can be taken care at source level (making sure to populate the custom attribute only if user has permission to access SAC)

‚ö†Ô∏èTo configure this job, you can modify the existing target or create a new one. If creating a new target, an SAP support ticket is required to set credentials (OAuth token URL, Client ID, and Secret).

üìãStep-by-Step: Hybrid Integration with External Source

  1. Integrate SAP SuccessFactors with Identity Authentication: Run the upgrade job in the SAP SuccessFactors Upgrade Center to enable features and establish trust between SF and CIS.
  2. Review the default configurations: Review the default configuration of the Identity Authentication service to determine if it meets your requirements or if additional configuration is required.
  3. Create Admin User for SCIM Access: Use SCIM APIs to push user records from the external system.
  4. Retain Global User ID (Optional): If needed, set the Global User ID in CIS to a unique external ID or let the system generate one. This Global User Id needs to be updated in SF at (personKeyNav/GlobalUserId).
  5. Sync to SAC
    Run a custom job (IAS ‚Üí SAC) to:
    • Check SAC access rights.
    • Create users accordingly.

‚öôÔ∏è Addressing Common Technical Challenges in Hybrid Integration

1: Managing Different Subject Name Identifiers (SNI) Across Applications

In hybrid, multi-application environments, it's common for login identifiers to vary across systems. SAP CIS supports multiple Subject Name Identifiers (SNI) per application, allowing flexibility. For scenarios where CIS login name is taken by another application as the identifier and it doesn't have the same value as username in SF then any other field supported field can be used for SNI. 

For SAP SuccessFactors (SF), it's essential to ensure that the runtime value of the SNI must align with the SF username field to enable proper user identification.

Note: Expression-based SNI mapping is supported, but functionality is currently limited. Use with caution and review configuration thoroughly before implementation

2: Can SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Work Without a Direct Sync from SF to CIS?

Yes, Though it is recommended to sync it from SF SAC does not require a direct user synchronization from SF. However, there's a critical requirement to enable user access:

Ensure CustomAttribute1 is correctly populated, as it is used to determine analytics access. Regardless of the data source, this attribute must be synced to SAC via CIS.

3: Can CustomAttribute1 Be Replaced with Another Attribute?

Absolutely. CustomAttribute1 is just a label. In SAP CIS, custom attributes are internally stored as an array, offering flexibility in how they're used.

If you choose to use a different custom attribute:

  • Ensure the transformation logic is updated accordingly, to confirm that consuming applications (e.g., SAC) are configured to read the new attribute.

  • Update the SNI mapping to reference the correct custom attribute.

4: Connecting Multiple SF Tenants to a Single CIS Tenant (with SAC for Each SF)

While technically possible, connecting multiple SuccessFactors tenants to the same CIS tenant, each with its own SAC instance, but it is not recommended. This setup introduces significant complexity in Managing user states across tenants.    

Conclusion

Integrating SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Cloud Identity Services offers flexibility, security, and alignment with SAP‚Äôs innovation roadmap. Whether through standard integration or a hybrid identity landscape using external IdPs, these methods empower organizations to centralize access control, reduce redundancy, and prepare for emerging technologies like SAP Joule.

entry.title: Protect Your SAP S/4HANA from Critical Code Injection Vulnerability [CVE-2025-42957]
entry.content:
Protect Your SAP S/4HANA from Critical Code Injection Vulnerability [CVE-2025-42957] with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection and SAP Enterprise Threat Detection, cloud edition.

A critical ABAP code injection vulnerability (CVE-2025-42957) has been discovered in SAP S/4HANA (Private Cloud or On-Premise), exposing SAP systems to potential exploits. This vulnerability allows attackers with user privileges to inject arbitrary ABAP code, bypassing essential authorization checks and putting the entire system at risk of compromise.

Key Details:

  • Vulnerability ID: CVE-2025-42957

  • CVSS v3.0 Base Score: 9.9 / 10

  • Impacted Components: S4CORE 102 - 108

Understanding the Threat:

This flaw operates as a backdoor, allowing unauthorized access to SAP systems and jeopardizing confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Without immediate mitigation, your SAP S/4HANA system could be severely compromised.

Monitoring with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection (SAP ETD):

SAP Enterprise Threat Detection plays a crucial role in identifying and mitigating such vulnerabilities. By adding the function module /SLOAE/DEPLOY to the value list ABAP Blocklisted Function Modules, SAP Enterprise Threat Detection can monitor and flag potential exploitation of this vulnerability.

Additionally, SAP Enterprise Threat Detection can be configured to track the frequency and context of calls to this critical function module. In a recent review of a production system landscape containing 34bn log events it was observed that this function module was not called at all over the last several months, validating its inclusion in threat detection parameters avoiding fals positives.

Steps to Secure Your SAP System:

  1. Patch Installation: Apply the correction instructions or support packages referenced by SAP Note 3627998 to eliminate code injection risks today!

  2. SAP Enterprise Threat Detection Monitoring: Add /SLOAE/DEPLOY to ABAP Blocklisted Function Modules in SAP Enterprise Threat Detection to monitor attempts to exploit this vulnerability.

  3. System Audits: Regularly audit your system for unauthorized access, privileged access, fraudulat behaviour and other signs of exploitation with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection.

For further information and the latest updates, refer to the SAP Security Note 3627998.

SAP Enterprise Threat Detection information: sap.com

Kind regards,

Arndt

Stay vigilant and ensure your SAP systems are protected from evolving threats.

entry.title: Holiday Readiness ‚Äì Secure Your Backoffice Before Peak Season
entry.content:
As part of the SAP Holiday Season Readiness Program, we‚Äôre helping you prepare for record-breaking traffic and sales. One critical step: protect your Backoffice and HAC from public exposure.

 

Why It Matters

Your Backoffice powers essential operations behind the scenes, non-customer-facing operations that supports crucial administrative and operational functions to ensure an e-commerce business runs smoothly, allowing businesses to scale.

Your Backoffice/HAC has administrative privileges in your e-commerce data and should not strictly be accessible publicly. It is vital to make sure that the environments are secure, to avoid a strong possibility of an attack leveraging them. If exposed to the internet, it becomes a high-value target for attackers‚Äîespecially during the holiday rush.

Risks of Exposure

  • üîì Unauthorized Access - Attackers can discover and access internal systems without authentication barriers.
  • ü§ñ Brute Force & Credential Stuffing Attacks - Login portals are targeted with automated password-guessing tools.
  • üïµÔ∏è‚Äç Sensitive Data Exposure - Internal dashboards or APIs may leak customer PII, business data, or system logs.
  • üí£ Malware & Ransomware Infection - Open endpoints can be used to deploy malicious payloads to internal systems.
  • ‚¨ÜÔ∏è Privilege Escalation - If attackers get in, they may gain administrative privileges and full control of the backend.
  • üìâ Reputational and Operational Impact - Downtime, data loss, and customer trust erosion can result from a breach.

How to Protect

  • Remove 0.0.0.0/0 (allow all) from your allow list.
  • Implement IP Filters and VPN for secure access.

üìö SAP Guidelines:

  • IP Filter Configuration
  • VPN Setup

Act now to secure your Backoffice before the holiday surge.

entry.title: Prevent Sensitive Data Exposure in URLs
entry.content:
High traffic means more transactions‚Äîand more risk. A common misconfiguration during integrations is sending PII data in the URL of a POST request instead of in the request body. This can lead to serious data leaks.

 

Why It‚Äôs Dangerous

URLs can be logged, cached, and exposed in browser history or analytics tools, making sensitive data vulnerable.

üîçLearn more: OWASP Guidelines

How to Fix It

  • Configure the POST request in a secured way. Always send PII in the body of the POST request, never in the URL.

üìö SAP Guidelines:

  • SAP CX Commerce Cloud Security Guide

Secure your integrations now to protect customer trust during peak season.

entry.title: Eliminate Default Password Risks
entry.content:
Default passwords are an open invitation for attackers and should not be in use in your environments. All default passwords involved should be changed immediately to make sure that your environments are safe and secure. With holiday traffic surging, the stakes are higher than ever.

 

What‚Äôs at Risk

  • üîì Unauthorized Access - Attackers can log in easily using well-known default credentials.
  • üí• Website Defacement - Hackers may change content, inject malicious scripts, or vandalize the site.
  • üõ† Privilege Escalation - Default credentials may allow full admin access.
  • üìâ Reputational Damage - Compromises can erode user trust and damage your brand.

What You Should Do

  • Change all default passwords immediately.
  • Regularly review and update credentials.

entry.title: Get & Stay Secure in the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Security Chapter
entry.content:
When moving to the public cloud with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP is taking care of many security relates topics as cloud provider. However, in order to stay secure, customers are still responsible for the mitigation of risks such as business or technical users having critical authorizations.

Here, the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report in SAP for Me comes into play as it gives you insights into security risks in the chapter "Security (Public Cloud)". This chapter gives you insights and alerts you on the following topics:

  • Identity and Access Management - get additional information and resources on how to use Identity and Access Management (IAM) to establish, tailor, and monitor business roles to business needs and requirements
  • Deprecated Business Catalogs - revise deprecated business catalogs still in use that might be removed in future releases
  • Business Users Assigned to Many Business Roles - get alerted when business users have many business roles assigned, deviating from the best practice of only one per business user
  • Assignment of users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR - check for usage of this role resulting in segregation of duties (SoD) conflicts as it is intended only for the initial configuration of a system
  • Use of Read/Write Unrestricted - be alerted on business roles having unrestricted write, read and value help access
  • Business Catalog Assignments - be warned about critical assignments of business catalogs to your business users
  • Communication (Inbound/Outbound) - find customer managed communication arrangements without certificate-based authentication using only basic authentication
  • Upcoming Certificate Expiration - early warning for certificates managed by the customer that will expire within the next 90 days

You can find more details on each of these chapters below or by directly accessing the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report* for your systems in SAP for Me. 

* an authorized users is needed to access this applicaion, refer to this SAP Support page on how to get access.

 

Identity and Access Management

Identity and Access Management (IAM) ensures that all business users within an organization have defined and managed business roles. With IAM, organizations can establish, tailor, and monitor business roles to business needs and requirements. There are several relevant applications available for managing IAM in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

The SAP EarlyWatch Alert provides an overview of relevant information and resources to enable the effective use of IAM.

 

Deprecated Business Catalogs

It is important to adapt existing Business Catalogs and Business Roles resulting from the addition of new scope items or a release upgrade. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Business Catalogs are periodically revised. Some Business Catalogs will be deprecated and replaced by new ones. The deprecated Business Catalogs in the system may be removed by SAP at the time of a release after it has been declared as deprecated, so it is important to review the deprecated Business Catalogs after each release along with new scope items and make the necessary changes as soon as possible.

In this chapter, a list of deprecated business catalogs in use in the system and information how to handle this is provided.

 

Business Users Assigned to Many Business Roles

SAP best practice is to assign only one business role to a business user. Each business role must represent a workplace and business roles should be created from scratch using the workplace approach.  For production, it is strongly recommended to build production roles manually to ensure compliance with external and internal compliance rules for access.

In the this chapter, the system is checked for users that have multiple business roles assigned.

 

Assignment of users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR

The role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR is predefined by SAP and is intended only for the initial configuration of a system. Usage of this role in production does not correspond to SAP recommendations and may lead to compliance issues.

The system is checked for the usage of this role in this chapter to alert on the potential risk that comes along with using it.

 

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted

Using unrestricted fields in the maintenance of business roles allow users to have global data access, SAP best practices recommend to carefully review which users need to have restricted data access and maintain the access appropriately, e.g. ensuring employees only have access to data belonging to their sales organization.

This chapter informs about the number of busines roles with unrestricted write, read or value help access.

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted Result Table Example

 

Business Catalog Assignments

Business catalogs contain a bundle of privileges needed for accessing an app or features that are then assigned to users via business roles. This section checks for selected critical business catalogs and their assignment to business roles and users and rates this according to the valuationrules from SAP Note 863362. In case any critical business catalogs are assigned, additional details are presented as sub-chapters.

Business Catalog Assignments Overview Table Example

 

Communication (Inbound/Outbound)

It is recommended that certificate-based communication is used for technical users involved in inbound/outbound communication when possible. Usually, it is easier to detect if a certificate is compromised than detect if a password has been compromised. This chapter identifies whether any customer managed communication arrangements do not use certificate-based authenticate and provides a list of them.

 

Upcoming Certificate Expiration

In case there are any certificates where their expiration date is coming up in the next 90 days, they will be listed in this chapter to notify about this early on.

 

 

Do you want to learn more on how to find and use the security relevant content in the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Workspace? Then check out this blog for more information.

Stay tuned for more content regarding Security in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition systems to be added to the SAP EarlyWatch Alert! üöÄ

entry.title: Q3 2025 Quarterly Release Highlights: SAP BTP Security and Identity & Access Management
entry.content:
Our development teams have been busy again this quarter, delivering a range of new features and enhancements across SAP BTP Security and Identity & Access Management.

Want the full overview? You can always find a list of all new feature announcements for SAP Cloud Identity Services in the SAP Cloud Identity Services Release Notes on the SAP Help Portal.

SAP Cloud Identity Services: CAPTCHA protection

Tenant administrators can enable CAPTCHA protection for the phone verification pages of the application. See the setup guidelines here:

  • Enable Google reCAPTCHA for Application Forms 
  • Enable MTCaptcha for Application Forms

SAP Cloud Identity Services: Provided APIs

Cloud Identity Services now expose the Identity Directory API, Corporate Identity Providers API, and SAP Cloud Identity Services Application Directory as provided APIs for the Administration Console application. These can be used for principal propagation.
Learn more in the documentation: Consume APIs from the Administration Console.

Identity Directory Service and Identity Provisioning Service: Support for extension schemas towards additional SAP business applications

Default transformations of the following connectors now support attributes from the SAP extension schema for groups, including application ID, type, and supported operations:

  • SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll
  • Cloud Foundry UAA Server
  • Procurement Data Warehouse

You can find details in the SAP Cloud Identity Services Release Notes.

Identity Provisioning Service: Enhanced real-time provisioning logs

Real-time sync execution results for source systems are now displayed in a dedicated table on the real-time provisioning logs screen.

Additional information is provided in the Reason column when an entity is skipped or not provisioned.
Check the guide on how to Monitor Real-Time Logs .

Custom Domain Service: New console client command and new optional parameter for generate-csr

Two new features are available for working with custom domains:

  • New console command: Use the add-domain-certificate command to add an already uploaded certificate of a different type to the SSL host. For example, if an RSA certificate is already bound to the SSL host, you can now also add an ECC certificate‚Äîand vice versa. For details, read  add-domain-certificate.
  • New parameter: The --elliptic-curve parameter can now be used with the generate-csr command, allowing you to specify an elliptic curve for ECC algorithms. Get the details at generate-csr.

Authorization and Trust Management Service: Automatic Signing Key Rotation for Access Tokens

We‚Äôre now offering automatic rotation of the signing key for access tokens. It is disabled by default; when enabled, SAP BTP rotates the signing key periodically. See Rotate Signing Keys of Access Tokens for details. As of January 2026, we plan to enable this feature by default for new subaccounts

entry.title: Minimizing SAP License Costs by optimizing SAP Authorizations with MOON Services
entry.content:

Efficient authorization management is crucial within the SAP environment for optimizing license costs. MOON Services aim to reduce authorizations to their necessary minimum, ensuring that what SAP users utilize is licensed, while optimizing unused authorizations. Let's explore the three essential MOON services: "MOON License Simulation", "MOON License Quickfix" and "MOON License Service powered by AIRC", each designed to enhance license management.

MOON License Simulation

MOON License Simulation focuses on precisely defining user license types in the SAP S/4HANA system through tailored authorizations to their essential minimum. This service enables companies to manage licenses efficiently and significantly reduce unnecessary costs.

Through simulation, customers can identify potential license cost optimizations when engaging in an authorization redesign with SAP Consulting. The service includes downloading usage data and calculating license costs for a new S/4HANA authorization concept against the requirements of the current STAR Service framework. Customers gain insight into possible license cost optimizations that can be achieved after an authorization redesign.


MOON License Quickfix

The MOON License Quickfix service offers rapid modifications to existing authorization structures, ensuring efficiency in license categorization. By analyzing current authorizations and making immediate role adjustments, companies can implement instant cost-saving measures.

This service focuses on reducing effort by minimizing authorization values and adapting authorization objects. By achieving quick wins in license type optimization, companies can significantly save costs while maintaining operational efficiency.


MOON License Service powered by AIRC

MOON License Service powered by AIRC (Automated Implementation of Role Concept) elevates license cost minimization to a new level, employing advanced automation and SAP Best Practices to refine authorizations. This service is designed to decrease effort and duration in managing roles and authorizations, enabling seamless cost management.

Driven by SAP AI Core automation, MOON AIRC precisely tailors authorizations to the necessary minimum, achieving substantial cost reductions and enhanced security. The service includes scoping, functional and organizational role definitions, and strategic role assignments‚Äîall aimed at minimizing license costs. Synchronization capabilities from SAP Signavio ensure a coherent approach to authorization management. In addition to optimizing license costs, this service delivers a high-quality, secure SAP Best Practice authorization concept.


Conclusion

The MOON services are at the forefront of license cost optimization, enabling companies to efficiently reduce authorizations to their necessary minimum. By focusing on precise authorization adjustments and employing automation, MOON Services empower organizations to achieve operational efficiency and substantial cost savings. Harness the potential of MOON Services and navigate your path to optimized license management and reduced overhead.
